html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From dē- (“down from”) +‎ cadō (“I fall”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈdeː.ki.doː/, [ˈd̪eː.kɪ.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈde.t͡ʃi.do/, [ˈd̪ɛː.t͡ʃi.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

dēcidō (present infinitive dēcidere, perfect active dēcidī); third conjugation, no passive, no supine stem

  1. (intransitive) I fall down or off; collapse; drop, hang down
  2. (intransitive) I die, fall dead
  3. (intransitive, figurative) I sink, perish
Conjugation[edit]

Derived terms[edit]
  • dēciduus
Related terms[edit]
  • accidō
  • cadō
  • concidō
  • excidō
  • incidō
  • intercidō
  • occidō
  • prōcidō
  • recidō
  • succidō
 
Descendants[edit]
  • English: decay, decadence, deciduous

Etymology 2[edit]

From dē- (“down from”) +‎ caedō (“I cut”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /deːˈkiː.doː/, [d̪eːˈkiː.d̪oː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /deˈt͡ʃi.do/, [d̪ɛˈt͡ʃiː.d̪ɔ]

Verb[edit]

dēcīdō (present infinitive dēcīdere, perfect active dēcīdī, supine dēcīsum); third conjugation

  1. I cut off or away; clip; reduce, diminish
  2. I beat severely, cudgel soundly, thrash
    Synonym: concīdō
  3. (figurative) I decide, determine, settle, terminate, put an end to; agree

Descendants[edit]
  • Catalan: decidir
  • Esperanto: decidi

  • French: décider

    • Occitan: decidar

  • Portuguese: decidir

  • Spanish: decidir

References[edit]

  • decido in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • decido in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • decido in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to fall to the earth: in terram cadere, decidere
  • decido in Ramminger, Johann (accessed 16 July 2016) Neulateinische Wortliste: Ein Wörterbuch des Lateinischen von Petrarca bis 1700‎[2], pre-publication website, 2005-2016
